title: Agent Guide
text: Purpose: Quick reference generic agent helping users psychinterpreter R package. technical/architectural details: See dev/DEVELOPER_GUIDE.md Status: Stable (2025-11-22) - Variable labeling functionality added Current API (2025-11-22): - Main entry points: interpret() (interpretations), label_variables() (variable labels) - Configuration objects: llm_args(), interpretation_args(), labeling_args(), output_args() - Architecture: - Interpretations: interpret() → interpret_model.{class}() → build_analysis_data.{class}() - Labels: label_variables() → build_system_prompt.label() → build_main_prompt.label() - S3 generics: build_analysis_data(), build_system_prompt(), build_main_prompt(), export_interpretation() - Parameter extraction: extract_model_parameters(), validate_model_requirements() Recent Updates (2025-11-22): - NEW: Variable labeling functionality label_variables(), reformat_labels(), export_labels() - Two-phase architecture: Semantic Generation (LLM) → Format Processing (post-processing) - Supports short (1-3 words), phrase (4-7 words), acronym (3-5 chars), custom labels - Extensive formatting options: case transformations, separators, abbreviation, article/preposition removal - Test coverage: 60+ tests labeling functionality

title: Agent Guide
text: : Automates interpretation psychometric analysis results generates concise variable labels using Large Language Models via ellmer package. Main Entry Points: - interpret() - Universal generic interpreting psychometric models (FA, GM, etc.) - label_variables() - Generate short, descriptive labels variable descriptions - chat_session() - Create persistent LLM session (saves ~40-60% tokens multiple analyses) Standards Examples/Tests: - Always use llm_provider = "ollama" llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" - LLM tests: word_limit = 20 (minimum allowed) token efficiency Documentation Structure: - AGENT.md (file): General usage guide agents. - CLAUDE.md: Model-specific guidance Claude. - GEMINI.md: Model-specific guidance Gemini. - dev/DEVELOPER_GUIDE.md: Technical architecture implementation details maintainers - dev/TESTING_GUIDELINES.md: Testing standards patterns - dev/templates/: Ready--copy code templates implementing new model types (GM, IRT, CDM) - dev/MODEL_IMPLEMENTATION_GUIDE.md: Step--step guide new model type implementation - dev/OPEN_ISSUES.md: Current issues, future work, priorities

title: Agent Guide
code: library(psychinterpreter)  # 1. Run factor analysis fa_result <- psych::fa(data, nfactors = 3)  # 2. Prepare variable descriptions var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("var1", "var2", ...),   description = c("Description of variable 1", "Description of variable 2", ...) )  # 3. Get interpretation interpretation <- interpret(   fit_results = fa_result,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # 4. View and export results print(interpretation)                                    # Print report plot(interpretation)                                     # Visualize loadings export_interpretation(interpretation, "results.md", "md") # Export

title: Agent Guide
code: # Create session once (saves ~40-60% tokens) chat <- chat_session(   analysis_type = "fa",   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Reuse for multiple interpretations result1 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa1, variable_info = vars1) result2 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa2, variable_info = vars2) result3 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa3, variable_info = vars3)  # Check cumulative token usage print(chat)

title: Agent Guide
text: Generate short, descriptive labels variables using LLMs.
code: library(psychinterpreter)  # 1. Prepare variable descriptions var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("q1", "q2", "q3"),  # Optional - will auto-generate V1, V2, V3 if omitted   description = c(     "How satisfied are you with your job?",     "Rate your work-life balance",     "Years of experience in your field"   ) )  # 2. Generate labels (one-shot) labels <- label_variables(   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   label_type = "short"  # 1-3 words (default) )  # 3. View results print(labels) # ── Variable Labels Report ── # # ── Labeling Details ── # • Label type: short # • Variables labeled: 3 # # ── Generated Labels ── # Variable  Label # --------  ---------------- # q1        Job Satisfaction # q2        Work Balance # q3        Experience Years  # 4. Reformat without calling LLM again labels_snake <- reformat_labels(labels, case = "snake") labels_camel <- reformat_labels(labels, case = "camel") labels_abbrev <- reformat_labels(labels, abbreviate = TRUE, max_words = 2)  # 5. Export to file export_labels(labels, "variable_labels.csv")  # CSV (default) export_labels(labels, "variable_labels.xlsx", format = "xlsx")  # Excel

title: Agent Guide
text: short (1-3 words): "Job Satisfaction", "Work Balance" [default] phrase (4-7 words): "Satisfaction Current Job Position" acronym (3-5 chars): "JOBSAT", "WRKBAL" custom: Use max_words parameter exact control

title: Agent Guide
code: labels <- label_variables(   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   label_type = "short",    # Semantic generation (LLM instructions)   max_words = 2,              # Override label_type preset   style_hint = "technical",   # Guide LLM style (e.g., "simple", "academic")    # Format processing (post-processing)   case = "snake",             # "lower", "upper", "title", "snake", "camel", "constant"   sep = "_",                  # Separator between words   remove_articles = TRUE,     # Remove "a", "an", "the"   remove_prepositions = TRUE, # Remove "of", "in", "at", etc.   abbreviate = TRUE,          # Apply rule-based abbreviation   max_chars = 20              # Maximum character length )

title: Agent Guide
text: package supports dual interface pattern maximum flexibility: can pass parameters either directly configuration objects.
code: # Create configuration objects for reusable settings interp_config <- interpretation_args(   analysis_type = "fa",   cutoff = 0.3,   n_emergency = 3,   hide_low_loadings = FALSE )  llm_config <- llm_args(   word_limit = 100,   additional_info = "Study context: personality assessment" )  output_config <- output_args(   format = "markdown",   silent = FALSE )  # Use configuration objects interpret(   fit_results = fa_result,   variable_info = var_info,   interpretation_args = interp_config,   llm_args = llm_config,   output_args = output_config,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Or mix config objects with direct parameters interpret(   fit_results = fa_result,   variable_info = var_info,   interpretation_args = interp_config,  # Use config for interpretation settings   llm_provider = "ollama",               # Direct parameters for LLM   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   word_limit = 150                       # Direct parameter OVERRIDES llm_args )

title: Agent Guide
text: configuration objects direct parameters provided: Direct parameters always take precedence: word_limit = 150 overrides llm_args = llm_args(word_limit = 100) Configuration objects provide defaults: direct parameter specified, uses value config object Package defaults fallback: neither provided, uses package defaults Example: use configuration objects: - Reusing settings across multiple analyses - Sharing configurations team workflows - Programmatically building complex configurations - Cleaner code passing many parameters use direct parameters: - Simple, one-analyses - Quick overrides config object values - Learning package (explicit) Pattern selection guide: - Single analysis: Pattern 1 (fitted model) - simplest - Multiple analyses: Pattern 3 (chat session) - efficient - Custom data: Pattern 2 (structured list) - Reusable settings: Pattern 4 (configuration objects) - flexible
code: # llm_config specifies word_limit = 100 llm_config <- llm_args(word_limit = 100)  interpret(   ...,   llm_args = llm_config,  # word_limit = 100   word_limit = 150        # This takes precedence! Final word_limit = 150 )

code: # Show common parameters for all models (llm_args + output_args) show_interpret_args()  # Show all parameters for Factor Analysis (includes FA-specific interpretation_args) show_interpret_args("fa")  # Show all parameters for Gaussian Mixture Models (includes GM-specific interpretation_args) show_interpret_args("gm")  # Capture parameter data programmatically params_df <- show_interpret_args("fa") print(params_df)

code: # Emergency rule: use top N loadings if none exceed cutoff interpret(..., n_emergency = 2)  # Use top 2 loadings (default) interpret(..., n_emergency = 0)  # Label weak factors as "undefined"  # Hide non-significant loadings to save tokens interpret(..., hide_low_loadings = TRUE)

title: Agent Guide
code: library(mclust)  # Fit Gaussian Mixture Model data_scaled <- scale(data) gmm_model <- Mclust(data_scaled, G = 1:5)  # Get interpretation gm_result <- interpret(   fit_results = gmm_model,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   weight_by_uncertainty = TRUE,  # Weight by assignment certainty   plot_type = "auto"              # Auto-select visualization )  # Multiple visualization types plot(gm_result, plot_type = "heatmap")    # Cluster means heatmap plot(gm_result, plot_type = "parallel")   # Parallel coordinates plot(gm_result, plot_type = "radar")      # Radar/spider plots plot(gm_result, plot_type = "all")        # All visualizations  # Visualize cluster variances (NEW in 0.0.0.9000) # The 'what' parameter controls which data to visualize: # - "means" (default): Cluster means (standardized values) # - "variances": Within-cluster standard deviations # - "ratio": Between/within variance ratios (discrimination power)  # Show within-cluster variability plot(gm_result, plot_type = "heatmap", what = "variances")    # Variance heatmap plot(gm_result, plot_type = "parallel", what = "variances")   # Variance parallel plot plot(gm_result, plot_type = "radar", what = "variances")      # Variance radar plot  # Show discrimination power (which variables best separate clusters) plot(gm_result, plot_type = "heatmap", what = "ratio")       # Ratio heatmap plot(gm_result, plot_type = "parallel", what = "ratio")      # Ratio parallel plot plot(gm_result, plot_type = "radar", what = "ratio")         # Ratio radar plot  # All visualizations for variance plot(gm_result, plot_type = "all", what = "variances")        # All variance plots  # Data centering options (NEW in 0.0.0.9000) # The 'centering' parameter helps highlight cluster differences by removing baseline effects # Only applies when what="means" (not for variances or ratios)  # Center each variable by its mean across clusters (removes variable-specific baselines) plot(gm_result, plot_type = "heatmap", centering = "variable")    # Variable-centered heatmap plot(gm_result, plot_type = "parallel", centering = "variable")   # Variable-centered parallel plot plot(gm_result, plot_type = "radar", centering = "variable")      # Variable-centered radar plot  # Center all values by the grand mean (common reference point) plot(gm_result, plot_type = "heatmap", centering = "global")      # Global-centered heatmap plot(gm_result, plot_type = "parallel", centering = "global")     # Global-centered parallel plot plot(gm_result, plot_type = "radar", centering = "global")        # Global-centered radar plot  # GM-specific parameters interpret(   fit_results = gmm_model,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   min_cluster_size = 10,              # Minimum viable cluster size   separation_threshold = 0.4,         # Overlap detection threshold   profile_variables = c("var1", "var2", "var3"),  # Focus on subset   weight_by_uncertainty = TRUE        # Consider assignment uncertainty )

title: Agent Guide
code: # Generate labels with different formats var_info <- data.frame(   description = c(     "How satisfied are you with your job?",     "Rate your work-life balance",     "Years of experience"   ) )  # Short labels (1-3 words) labels_short <- label_variables(   var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   label_type = "short" )  # Snake case for programming labels_snake <- reformat_labels(labels_short, case = "snake") # Result: "job_satisfaction", "work_balance", "experience_years"  # Abbreviated for plots labels_abbrev <- reformat_labels(   labels_short,   abbreviate = TRUE,   max_words = 2,   max_chars = 12 )  # Using configuration objects (dual-tier architecture) label_config <- labeling_args(   label_type = "short",   case = "snake",   remove_articles = TRUE )  llm_config <- llm_args(   echo = "none" )  labels <- label_variables(   var_info,   labeling_args = label_config,   llm_args = llm_config,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Direct parameters override config objects labels <- label_variables(   var_info,   labeling_args = label_config,  # says case = "snake"   case = "camel",                 # This takes precedence!   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: psychinterpreter package automatically interprets psychometric analysis results using Large Language Models (LLMs). LLMs AI systems (like ChatGPT, Claude, open-source alternatives) can understand generate human-like text. Instead manually examining complex statistical output guessing patterns represent, get clear, human-readable interpretations actionable insights. package also provides variable labeling functionality generate short, descriptive labels variable descriptions, making data results readable. Currently supported analyses: Factor Analysis - Interpret factor loadings suggest meaningful factor names Planned analysis classes: Gaussian Mixture Models - Interpret cluster profiles Item Response Theory (IRT) - Interpret item diagnostics Cognitive Diagnostic Models (CDM) - Interpret Q-matrix patterns Use package : run psychometric analysis (e.g., factor analysis, clustering) Want automated, data-driven interpretations results Need quickly understand complex patterns data

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: starting, make sure : Analysis results - psych::fa(), lavaan::efa(), similar functions Variable descriptions - brief explanations variable measures language model - recommend Ollama (free, runs locally, offers cloud-powered models Ollama account)

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: ’s complete workflow factor analysis using Big Five personality data just lines:
code: library(psychinterpreter) library(psych) library(ollamar)  # 1. Describe your variables var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("A1", "A2", "A3", ...),   description = c("Am indifferent to others", "Inquire about others", ...) )  # 2. Generate short labels (optional) labels <- label_variables(   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   max_words = 3,   case = "title" )  # 3. Run factor analysis fa_result <- psych::fa(bfi[,1:25], nfactors = 5, rotate = "oblimin")  # 4. Get LLM interpretation interpretation <- interpret(   fit_results = fa_result,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # 5. View results print(interpretation) plot(interpretation)

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: tutorial demonstrates package using factor analysis, workflow applies analysis types become available. Let’s walk complete example using Big Five Inventory (BFI) personality data. Load packages ’ll need: BFI dataset contains 25 personality items measuring Big Five traits. ’s data looks like: item descriptions: Create data frame mapping variable names descriptions: running analysis, can use LLMs generate short, descriptive labels variable descriptions. makes analysis output plots readable: Now replace original variable names short labels: Tip Label Formatting Options label_variables() function offers extensive formatting control: Label types: label_type = "short" (1-3 words), "phrase" (4-7 words), "acronym" (3-5 chars) Case transformations: case = "snake", "camel", "title", "upper", etc. Simplification: remove_articles = TRUE, remove_prepositions = TRUE, abbreviate = TRUE Reformatting: Use reformat_labels() change formatting without calling LLM See ?label_variables options. Now perform standard exploratory factor analysis 5 factors using labeled data: View factor loadings (now readable labels): Now use interpret() get automatic factor interpretations: Note First time using Ollama? Install Ollama ollama.com ollamar package: install.packages("ollamar") Pull model: ollamar::pull("gpt-oss:20b-cloud") Start Ollama server running interpret() Print interpretation report: output shows: - Suggested factor names - variables load factor - brief interpretation factor represents View suggested factor names: Create visual representation factor loadings:  plot shows variables load strongly factor, making easy see factor structure glance. Save interpretation file:
code: # Install pacman if needed for easy package loading if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")  # Load packages pacman::p_load(   "psychinterpreter",  # This package   "psych",             # For factor analysis   "reactable",         # For nice tables   "dplyr",             # For data manipulation   "pander"             # package for pretty printing ) # Load Big Five Inventory data data("bfi") data("bfi.dictionary")  # Keep only the 25 personality items (remove demographics) bfi_items <- bfi[, 1:25] bfi_dict <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ] head(bfi_items, 5) |>   as.data.frame() |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE) bfi_dict |>   select(Item) |>   as.data.frame() |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10) variable_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi_dict),   description = as.character(bfi_dict$Item),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  head(variable_info, 10) |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE) provider <- "anthropic" llm <- ellmer::models_anthropic()[1,"id"] # Generate short labels (1-3 words each) bfi_labels <- label_variables(   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = provider,   llm_model = llm,   max_words = 3,        # Keep labels concise   sep = "_",            # Use underscores between words   case = "title"        # Title Case format ) # Create new variable names combining original names with labels labels <- paste(   bfi_labels$labels_formatted$variable,   bfi_labels$labels_formatted$label,   sep = "-" )  # Apply to data and variable_info colnames(bfi_items) <- labels variable_info$variable <- labels  # Show updated variable info head(variable_info, 10) |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE) fa_result <- psych::fa(   bfi_items,  # N1-Anger_Proneness, Get angry easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .852)   2. N2-Irritability, Get irritated easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .817)   3. N3-Mood_Swings, Have frequent mood swings. (Positive, Strong, .665)   4. N5-Panic_Proneness, Panic easily. (Positive, Moderate, .439)   5. N4-Depressive_Mood, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .413)  LLM Interpretation: This factor represents neuroticism and emotional reactivity, capturing the tendency toward negative affect and emotional dysregulation. Anger proneness (0.852) and irritability (0.817) are the primary markers, with mood swings (0.665), panic proneness (0.439), and depressive mood (0.413) providing secondary indicators. The factor reflects a dispositional vulnerability to experiencing intense, unstable emotions across various contexts. A5-Put_At_Ease, Make people feel at ease. (Positive, Strong, .577)   4. A4-Love_Children, Love children. (Positive, Moderate, .456)   5. E4-Make_Friends_Easily, Make friends easily. (Positive, Moderate, .362)   6. A1-Indifferent_To_Others, Am indifferent to the feelings of others.   (Negative, Moderate, -.360)   7. E3-Captivate_People, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Moderate,   .303)  LLM Interpretation: This factor measures interpersonal warmth and empathic responsiveness, characterized by genuine concern for others' emotional states and comfort. Strong loadings on comfort others (0.668), inquire well-being (0.603), and put at ease (0.577) indicate prosocial and nurturing tendencies. The negative loading on indifference (−0.360) reinforces orientation toward others' needs. Secondary loadings on make friends easily (0.362) and captivate people (0.303) suggest interpersonal facilitation. Notably, love children (0.456) reflects compassion toward vulnerable populations. This factor represents agreeableness and empathy, demonstrating convergent validity through theoretically coherent emotional and social variables.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 3 (ML1) - Social Withdrawal Number of significant loadings: 7 Variance explained: 8.28% Factor Correlations: ML2 = .23, ML5 = -.31, ML3 = -.22, ML4 = -.17  Variables:   1. E2-Difficulty_Approaching, Find it difficult to approach others. (Positive,   Strong, .667)   2. E1-Quiet, Don't talk a lot. (Positive, Strong, .565)   3. E4-Make_Friends_Easily, Make friends easily. (Negative, Strong, -.527)   4. N4-Depressive_Mood, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .420)   5. E5-Take_Charge, Take charge. (Negative, Moderate, -.394)   6. O4-Reflective, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Moderate, .357)   7. E3-Captivate_People, Know how to captivate people. (Negative, Moderate,   -.341)  LLM Interpretation: This factor captures introversion and social inhibition, defined by difficulty in interpersonal engagement and avoidance of social interaction. Difficulty approaching others (0.667) and quietness (0.565) are primary indicators of social hesitance, with strong negative loadings on social facilitation: make friends easily (−0.527), take charge (−0.394), and captivate people (−0.341). Secondary loadings on depressive mood (0.420) and reflective (0.357) suggest accompanying introspection or withdrawal-related mood. This factor represents the introverted end of extraversion, distinct from social competence. The pattern demonstrates discriminant validity from empathy, measuring behavioral social inhibition rather than emotional warmth.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 4 (ML3) - Conscientious Organization Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 8.19% Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.21, ML5 = .20, ML1 = -.22, ML4 = .20  Variables:   1. Secondary positive loading on take charge (0.274) suggests assertive implementation of standards. title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Load packages ’ll need:
code: # Install pacman if needed for easy package loading if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")  # Load packages pacman::p_load(   "psychinterpreter",  # This package   "psych",             # For factor analysis   "reactable",         # For nice tables   "dplyr",             # For data manipulation   "pander"             # package for pretty printing )

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: BFI dataset contains 25 personality items measuring Big Five traits. ’s data looks like: item descriptions:
code: # Load Big Five Inventory data data("bfi") data("bfi.dictionary")  # Keep only the 25 personality items (remove demographics) bfi_items <- bfi[, 1:25] bfi_dict <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ] head(bfi_items, 5) |>   as.data.frame() |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE) bfi_dict |>   select(Item) |>   as.data.frame() |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10)

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Create data frame mapping variable names descriptions:
code: variable_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi_dict),   description = as.character(bfi_dict$Item),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  head(variable_info, 10) |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE)

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: running analysis, can use LLMs generate short, descriptive labels variable descriptions. makes analysis output plots readable: Now replace original variable names short labels: Tip Label Formatting Options label_variables() function offers extensive formatting control: Label types: label_type = "short" (1-3 words), "phrase" (4-7 words), "acronym" (3-5 chars) Case transformations: case = "snake", "camel", "title", "upper", etc. Simplification: remove_articles = TRUE, remove_prepositions = TRUE, abbreviate = TRUE Reformatting: Use reformat_labels() change formatting without calling LLM See ?label_variables options.
code: provider <- "anthropic" llm <- ellmer::models_anthropic()[1,"id"] # Generate short labels (1-3 words each) bfi_labels <- label_variables(   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = provider,   llm_model = llm,   max_words = 3,        # Keep labels concise   sep = "_",            # Use underscores between words   case = "title"        # Title Case format ) # Create new variable names combining original names with labels labels <- paste(   bfi_labels$labels_formatted$variable,   bfi_labels$labels_formatted$label,   sep = "-" )  # Apply to data and variable_info colnames(bfi_items) <- labels variable_info$variable <- labels  # Show updated variable info head(variable_info, 10) |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE)

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Now perform standard exploratory factor analysis 5 factors using labeled data: View factor loadings (now readable labels):
code: fa_result <- psych::fa(   bfi_items,  # Now contains labeled variables   nfactors = 5,   rotate = "oblimin",  # Oblique rotation   fm = "ml"            # Maximum likelihood ) # Extract and display loadings loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |>   as.data.frame()  round(loadings_matrix, 2) |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE)

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Now use interpret() get automatic factor interpretations: Note First time using Ollama? Install Ollama ollama.com ollamar package: install.packages("ollamar") Pull model: ollamar::pull("gpt-oss:20b-cloud") Start Ollama server running interpret()
code: interpretation <- interpret(   fit_results = fa_result,   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = provider,   llm_model = llm,   silent = 1  # Will print explicitly below )

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Q: LLM interpretation seems wrong? LLM bases interpretations variable descriptions statistical results. can: Provide better, descriptive variable descriptions Use bigger LLM. Small models may struggle task structured output requirements. Adjust cutoff hide_low_loadings parameters change results included Add context additional_info parameter Q: Can use different LLMs? Yes! package supports providers supported ellmer package, example: Ollama (local, free): llm_provider = "ollama" OpenAI (API key required): llm_provider = "openai" Anthropic Claude (API key required): llm_provider = "anthropic" Q: set API keys OpenAI Anthropic? Also refer documentation ellmer https://ellmer.tidyverse.org/ package.
code: # Add to your .Renviron file: Sys.setenv(OPENAI_API_KEY = "your-key-here") Sys.setenv(ANTHROPIC_API_KEY = "your-key-here")

title: Variable Labeling with LLMs
text: label_variables() function uses Large Language Models generate short, descriptive labels variable descriptions. especially useful : Psychometric data cryptic item codes (e.g., A1, C2, E3) Survey data generic names (e.g., q1, q2, item_01) dataset variable names need descriptive function works two phases: Semantic Generation: LLM creates meaningful labels descriptions Format Processing: Apply transformations (case, separators, abbreviations, etc.) separation allows reformat labels without calling LLM , saving time API costs.

title: Variable Labeling with LLMs
code: # Load packages if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")  pacman::p_load(   "psychinterpreter",  # This package   "psych",             # For BFI data   "reactable"          # For nice tables )

title: Variable Labeling with LLMs
text: BFI dataset contains 25 personality items cryptic codes like A1, C2, E3: cryptic codes (A1, A2, etc.) readable. Let’s generate descriptive labels!
code: # Load Big Five Inventory data data("bfi", package = "psych") data("bfi.dictionary", package = "psych")  # Extract first 10 items as examples bfi_subset <- bfi[, 1:10] bfi_dict <- bfi.dictionary[1:10, ]  # Create variable_info data frame variable_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi_dict),   description = as.character(bfi_dict$Item),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Show the data reactable(variable_info, striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10)

title: Variable Labeling with LLMs
text: specify max_words max_chars label_variables(), influence LLM prompt generate labels within constraints. effective post-processing truncation. Important: max_words max_chars override label_type presets except “acronym”. acronyms, max_chars used (controlling acronym length), max_words ignored. Key differences: - max_words/max_chars label_variables(): Guides LLM generate appropriate labels (upper limits) - max_words/max_chars reformat_labels(): Truncates existing labels (less intelligent) - Exception: max_words ignored label_type = "acronym" (use max_chars instead)
code: # Set provider and model provider <- "anthropic" llm <- ellmer::models_anthropic()[1, "id"] labels_short <- label_variables(   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = provider,   llm_model = llm,   max_words = 1,   max_chars = 20,   label_type = "short",  # 1-3 words   case = "title",        # Title Case   silent = 1             # Suppress automatic print ) # View results labels_short$labels_formatted |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10) labels_phrase <- label_variables(   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = provider,   llm_model = llm,   label_type = "phrase",  # 4-7 words   case = "sentence",      # Sentence case   silent = 1              # Suppress automatic print ) labels_phrase$labels_formatted |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10) labels_acronym <- label_variables(   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = provider,   llm_model = llm,   label_type = "acronym",  # 3-5 character acronyms   case = "upper",          # UPPERCASE   silent = 1               # Suppress automatic print ) labels_acronym$labels_formatted |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10) # max_words overrides "short" preset (1-3 words) to generate up to 2 words labels_two_words <- label_variables(   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = provider,   llm_model = llm,   label_type = "short",   # Would normally be 1-3 words   max_words = 2,          # But max_words limits to up to 2 words   case = "title",   silent = 1              # Suppress automatic print ) labels_two_words$labels_formatted |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10) # max_chars works with all label types, including acronyms labels_short_chars <- label_variables(   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = provider,   llm_model = llm,   label_type = "short",   # Would normally be 1-3 words   max_chars = 12,         # Adds character limit constraint   case = "snake",   silent = 1              # Suppress automatic print ) labels_short_chars$labels_formatted |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10) # For acronyms, max_chars controls the acronym length (max_words is ignored) labels_long_acronym <- label_variables(   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = provider,   llm_model = llm,   label_type = "acronym",   max_chars = 8,          # Acronyms up to 8 characters (instead of default 3-5)   max_words = 2,          # This is IGNORED for acronyms   case = "upper",   silent = 1              # Suppress automatic print ) labels_long_acronym$labels_formatted |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10)

title: Variable Labeling with LLMs
text: specify max_words max_chars label_variables(), influence LLM prompt generate labels within constraints. effective post-processing truncation. Important: max_words max_chars override label_type presets except “acronym”. acronyms, max_chars used (controlling acronym length), max_words ignored. Key differences: - max_words/max_chars label_variables(): Guides LLM generate appropriate labels (upper limits) - max_words/max_chars reformat_labels(): Truncates existing labels (less intelligent) - Exception: max_words ignored label_type = "acronym" (use max_chars instead)
code: # max_words overrides "short" preset (1-3 words) to generate up to 2 words labels_two_words <- label_variables(   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = provider,   llm_model = llm,   label_type = "short",   # Would normally be 1-3 words   max_words = 2,          # But max_words limits to up to 2 words   case = "title",   silent = 1              # Suppress automatic print ) labels_two_words$labels_formatted |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10) # max_chars works with all label types, including acronyms labels_short_chars <- label_variables(   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = provider,   llm_model = llm,   label_type = "short",   # Would normally be 1-3 words   max_chars = 12,         # Adds character limit constraint   case = "snake",   silent = 1              # Suppress automatic print ) labels_short_chars$labels_formatted |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10) # For acronyms, max_chars controls the acronym length (max_words is ignored) labels_long_acronym <- label_variables(   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = provider,   llm_model = llm,   label_type = "acronym",   max_chars = 8,          # Acronyms up to 8 characters (instead of default 3-5)   max_words = 2,          # This is IGNORED for acronyms   case = "upper",   silent = 1              # Suppress automatic print ) labels_long_acronym$labels_formatted |>   reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10)

code: labels_simplified <- reformat_labels(   labels_phrase,   remove_articles = TRUE,       # Remove: a, an, the   remove_prepositions = TRUE,   # Remove: of, in, at, etc.   case = "snake" )  # Compare original phrase vs simplified comparison <- data.frame(   variable = labels_phrase$labels_formatted$variable,   original = labels_phrase$labels_formatted$label,   simplified = labels_simplified$labels_formatted$label )  reactable::reactable(comparison, defaultPageSize = 10) labels_abbreviated <- reformat_labels(   labels_phrase,   abbreviate = TRUE,  # Apply rule-based abbreviation   case = "snake" )  comparison_abbrev <- data.frame(   variable = labels_phrase$labels_formatted$variable,   original = labels_phrase$labels_formatted$label,   abbreviated = labels_abbreviated$labels_formatted$label )  reactable::reactable(comparison_abbrev, defaultPageSize = 10) labels_short_max <- reformat_labels(   labels_phrase,   max_chars = 15,  # Truncate to 15 characters (simple truncation)   case = "snake" )  comparison_max <- data.frame(   variable = labels_phrase$labels_formatted$variable,   original = labels_phrase$labels_formatted$label,   truncated = labels_short_max$labels_formatted$label )  reactable::reactable(comparison_max, defaultPageSize = 10) labels_limited_words <- reformat_labels(   labels_phrase,   max_words = 2,   # Keep only first 2 words (simple truncation)   case = "title" )  comparison_words <- data.frame(   variable = labels_phrase$labels_formatted$variable,   original = labels_phrase$labels_formatted$label,   limited = labels_limited_words$labels_formatted$label )  reactable::reactable(comparison_words, defaultPageSize = 10)

title: Variable Labeling with LLMs
text: label_variables() function provides: Semantic understanding: LLMs generate meaningful labels descriptions Flexible formatting: Multiple case styles, separators, transformations Efficient workflow: Reformat without re-calling LLM Multiple export options: CSV, JSON, R scripts Configuration reuse: Define , apply many times Key parameters: Important: - Parameters marked “LLM-Guided” influence model generates used label_variables(). parameters can also used reformat_labels() post-processing without calling LLM . - Exception: max_words ignored label_type = "acronym". acronyms, use max_chars control acronym length.

title: Cluster Analysis via Gaussian Mixture Models
text: document demonstrates Gaussian Mixture Model interpretation feature psychinterpreter package using Big Five personality data psych package. Big Five Inventory (BFI) widely-used personality assessment measures five major dimensions personality: Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, Neuroticism. also covers labeling variables using large language models (LLMs) create short labels better interpretability.

title: Cluster Analysis via Gaussian Mixture Models
code: packages <- c(   "psychinterpreter",   "ellmer",   "ollamar",   "psych",   "lavaan",   "mirt",   "mclust",   "dplyr",   "here",   "reactable",   "kableExtra",   "pander",   "patchwork" ) # Load required packages using pacman if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman") Loading required package: pacman pacman::p_load(char = packages)  # Load the BFI dataset and dictionary data("bfi") data("bfi.dictionary")

title: Cluster Analysis via Gaussian Mixture Models
text: Exclude demographic variables factor analysis Show first rows BFI data: Display BFI dictionary showing item descriptions:
code: bfi <- bfi[,1:25] bfi.dictionary <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ] head(bfi, 10) |> reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10) bfi.dictionary |> select(Item) |> as.data.frame() |> reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10)

title: Cluster Analysis via Gaussian Mixture Models
text: Create variable information dataframe BFI dictionary Replace variable names short labels update variable_info later use
code: variable_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi.dictionary),   description = as.character(bfi.dictionary$Item),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  variable_info |> reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE) provider <- "anthropic" llm <- ellmer::models_anthropic()[1,"id"] bfi_labels <- label_variables(   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = provider,   llm_model = llm,   llm_args  = list(params(temperature = 0, seed = 42)),   max_words = 3,   sep = "_",   case = "title",   silent = 0  # Suppress automatic print ) labels <- paste(bfi_labels$labels_formatted$variable, bfi_labels$labels_formatted$label, sep = "-") colnames(bfi) <- labels variable_info$variable <- labels

title: Cluster Analysis via Gaussian Mixture Models
text: Find Best Gaussian Mixture Model  Fit Best Model  may also extract mean vector, covariance matrix, mixing proportions, membership grades model fit provide directly interpret(). appropriate workflow models directly supported psychinterpreter. Let’s first take look required arguments generic interpretation function: Interpretation generic API
code: gmm_model <- mclustICL(ggplot2::remove_missing(bfi), G = 1:10, prior = priorControl()) Warning: Removed 364 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range. summary(gmm_model) Best ICL values:              VEV,2         VVV,2        EEE,2 ICL      -197755.8 -197777.02292 -197918.3304 ICL diff       0.0     -21.18924    -162.4967 plot(gmm_model) best_model <- pickBIC(gmm_model) # extract model name from best_model$names model_name <- names(best_model)[1] |> stringr::str_extract("[A-Z]{3}") n_clusters <- names(best_model)[1] |> stringr::str_extract("[1-9]") |> as.integer() # Run mclust with automatic model and cluster selection gm_result <- mclust::Mclust(   ggplot2::remove_missing(bfi),   G = n_clusters,   modelNames = model_name,   warn = TRUE,   prior = priorControl() ) Warning: Removed 364 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range. summary(gm_result) ---------------------------------------------------- Gaussian finite mixture model fitted by EM algorithm ----------------------------------------------------  Mclust VEV (ellipsoidal, equal shape) model with 2 components:  Prior: defaultPrior()   log-likelihood    n  df       BIC       ICL       -96047.78 2436 677 -197374.9 -197755.7  Clustering table:    1    2 1254 1182 # Get interpretation result <- interpret(   fit_results = gm_result,   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = provider,   llm_model = llm,   weight_by_uncertainty = TRUE,   word_limit = 50 ) ℹ Starting gm interpretation... ℹ Creating temporary chat session... ℹ Building prompt... ℹ Querying LLM... ℹ Parsing LLM response... ℹ Creating fit summary... ℹ Building report... ✔ Interpretation complete! Gaussian Mixture Model Interpretation: 2 Clusters ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Number of clusters: 2 Number of variables: 25 Number of observations: 2436 Covariance structure: VEV (ellipsoidal, varying volume, equal shape, varying orientation) BIC: -197374.89 AIC: 193449.56 ICL: -197755.65 Log-likelihood: -96047.78 Number of parameters: 677 Entropy: 403.737 Normalized entropy: 0.2391 Minimum cluster separation: 1.380 Converged: Yes LLM used: anthropic - claude-haiku-4-5-20251001 Tokens:   Input: 0   Output: 0 Elapsed time: 4.54     Suggested Cluster Names ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  • Cluster 1 (52.3%): Conflicted Emotional Responders • Cluster 2 (47.7%): Composed Achievers     Cluster Interpretations ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Cluster_1: "Conflicted Emotional Responders" (n=1274, 52.3%)   Emotionally turbulent individuals combining high conscientiousness with elevated neuroticism. They demonstrate strong   interpersonal concern but struggle with emotional regulation, showing anger proneness (0.76 correlation with   irritability), mood instability, and social anxiety. High openness and conscientiousness suggest intellectual   engagement paired with perfectionism, creating internal tension between ideals and emotional vulnerabilities.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Cluster_2: "Composed Achievers" (n=1162, 47.7%)   Emotionally stable, socially confident professionals with exceptional conscientiousness. They exhibit genuine empathy   without emotional volatility, strong leadership presence, and intellectual openness. Lower neuroticism, reduced social   anxiety, and minimal indifference to others define this group. Their distinguishing profile combines emotional   resilience, interpersonal warmth, and achievement orientation without the emotional turbulence of Cluster 1.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════     Diagnostics ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────     Warnings:     Poor cluster separation detected (minimum distance: 1.38)     Notes:     Overlapping cluster pairs: Cluster_1-Cluster_2    Key Distinguishing Variables ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────     Cluster_1: "Conflicted Emotional Responders":     - E4-Make_Friends_Easily (3.89 vs 4.43)     - E2-Difficulty_Approaching_Others (3.61 vs 3.13)     - A3-Comfort_Others (4.14 vs 4.62)     Cluster_2: "Composed Achievers":     - E4-Make_Friends_Easily (4.98 vs 4.43)     - E2-Difficulty_Approaching_Others (2.65 vs 3.13)     - A3-Comfort_Others (5.1 vs 4.62) plot(   result,   what = c("means"),   plot_type = "parallel",   centering = "global",   orientation = "vertical",   variable_order = "variance_reversed" ) +   ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "top") # Means gmm_means <- gm_result$parameters$mean  # Covariance Matrix: gmm_covariances <- gm_result$parameters$variance$sigma  # Mixing proportions gmm_proportions <- gm_result$parameters$pro  # z matrix as the membership grades for every person gmm_z <- gm_result$z show_interpret_args("gm") ── Llm args (llm_args) ──    • additional_info (character)     Default: NULL     Additional context for LLM    • echo (character)     Default: "none"     Allowed: "none", "output", "all"     Echo level: 'none', 'output', 'all'    • interpretation_guidelines (character)     Default: NULL     Custom interpretation guidelines for LLM    • llm_model (character)     Default: NULL     LLM model name (e.g., 'gpt-4o-mini', 'claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022')    • llm_provider (character (required))     Default: NULL     LLM provider name (e.g., 'anthropic', 'openai', 'ollama')    • params (list)     Default: NULL     ellmer params object (created via ellmer::params())    • system_prompt (character)     Default: NULL     Custom system prompt to override default    • word_limit (integer)     Default: 150     Range: 20-500     Maximum words for LLM interpretations   ── Output args (output_args) ──    • format (character)     Default: "cli"     Allowed: "cli", "markdown"     Output format: 'cli' or 'markdown'    • heading_level (integer)     Default: 1     Range: 1-6     Markdown heading level (1-6)    • max_line_length (integer)     Default: 80     Range: 40-300     Maximum line length for text wrapping (40-300)    • silent (integer)     Default: 0     Range: 0-2     Verbosity level: 0 (report+messages), 1 (messages only), 2 (silent)    • suppress_heading (logical)     Default: FALSE     Suppress main heading in output   ── Interpretation args (interpretation_args) - GM specific ──    • covariance_type (character)     Default: NULL     Allowed: "EII", "VII", "EEI", "VEI", "EVI", "VVI", "EEE", "VEE", "EVE", "VVE", "EEV", "VEV", "EVV", "VVV"     Covariance structure for mclust models (GM only)    • min_cluster_size (integer) title: LLM-powered interpretation for psychometric analyses
text: LLM-powered interpretation factor cluster analyses, plus variable label generation. Disclaimer: package early development used caution. Always review validate LLM-generated interpretations.

title: LLM-powered interpretation for psychometric analyses
text: 🤖 LLM-Powered Interpretation: Generate human-readable factor names interpretations using state---art language models via ‘ellmer’ package 🏷️ Variable Label Generation: Create short, descriptive labels variable descriptions extensive formatting options (case transformations, abbreviation, etc.) psych::fa() psych::principal() results lavaan::cfa(), lavaan::sem(), lavaan::efa() results mirt::mirt() multidimensional IRT results Auto-extracts loadings factor correlations 📊 Comprehensive Reports: Automatically generate detailed reports text markdown format 📈 Visualizations: Create publication-ready heatmaps factor loadings suggested factor names 💾 Multi-Format Export: Export results TXT MD formats 🎯 Provider Agnostic: Works OpenAI, Anthropic, Google Gemini, Azure, Ollama, via ‘ellmer’ 🔄 Persistent Chat Sessions: Reuse LLM sessions across multiple analyses save tokens reduce costs

title: LLM-powered interpretation for psychometric analyses
text: can install development version psychinterpreter GitHub:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("https://github.com/matthiaskloft/psychinterpreter")

title: LLM-powered interpretation for psychometric analyses
code: library(psychinterpreter) library(psych)  # Run factor analysis fa_result <- fa(bfi[, 1:25], nfactors = 5, rotate = "oblimin")  # Create variable information var_info <- data.frame(variable = rownames(bfi.dictionary[1:25, ]),                        description = bfi.dictionary$Item[1:25])  # Interpret directly from model object results <- interpret(   fa_result,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )

title: LLM-powered interpretation for psychometric analyses
text: control custom loadings matrices:
code: # Extract loadings manually loadings <- fa_result$loadings  # Use structured list with analysis_type results <- interpret(   fit_results = list(loadings = loadings),   variable_info = var_info,   analysis_type = "fa",   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )

title: LLM-powered interpretation for psychometric analyses
text: Use persistent chat sessions save tokens analyzing multiple datasets:
code: # Create reusable chat session chat <- chat_session(   analysis_type = "fa",   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Run multiple interpretations (saves ~40-60% tokens) result1 <- interpret(   chat_session = chat,   fit_results = fa_result1,   variable_info = var_info1,   silent = 2 ) result2 <- interpret(   chat_session = chat,   fit_results = fa_result2,   variable_info = var_info2 ) result3 <- interpret(   chat_session = chat,   fit_results = fa_result3,   variable_info = var_info3 )  # Check cumulative token usage print(chat)

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
code: chat_session(   analysis_type = "fa",   llm_provider,   llm_model = NULL,   system_prompt = NULL,   params = NULL,   echo = "none",   word_limit = 100 )

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
text: analysis_type Character. Type analysis: "fa" (factor analysis), "gm" (gaussian mixture), "irt" (item response theory), "cdm" (cognitive diagnosis model) llm_provider Character. LLM provider (e.g., "anthropic", "openai", "ollama") llm_model Character. Model name (e.g., "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001") system_prompt Character NULL. Optional custom system prompt text override model-specific default system prompt. Use provide institution- project-specific framing LLM (e.g., preferred terminology, audience level, reporting conventions). NULL, model-specific default system prompt used (default = NULL). params List. ellmer parameters (temperature, etc.). Default uses ellmer::params(). Note: providers may support parameters (e.g., Ollama support 'seed'). Unsupported parameters generate warnings ellmer affect functionality. echo Character. Echo level ("none", "output", ""). Default "none" word_limit Integer. Word limit interpretations (used system_prompt NULL). Default 100.

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
text: chat_session object containing persistent chat session

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
text: chat_session object stores: persistent ellmer chat session model-specific system prompt already loaded Analysis type, provider, model information Token usage tracking (cumulative input/output tokens across interpretations) Session metadata (number interpretations run, creation timestamp) allows efficient reuse across multiple interpretations without resending system prompt time. Token Tracking Note: package tracks per-interpretation token counts using roles returned ellmer::chat$get_tokens() (user/assistant). providers ellmer wrapper consistently expose system/system_prompt token counts (appears upstream limitation/bug). avoid incorrect cumulative accounting (double-counting negative accumulation), chat_session intentionally include system_prompt tokens package-level cumulative counters (total_input_tokens / total_output_tokens). require provider-specific view includes system prompt tokens, call chat$chat$get_tokens(include_system_prompt = TRUE) directly - note results may vary across providers.

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create a persistent chat session for factor analysis chat <- chat_session("fa", "anthropic", "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001")  # Use with multiple analyses result1 <- interpret_fa(loadings1, var_info1, chat_session = chat) result2 <- interpret_fa(loadings2, var_info2, chat_session = chat)  # Check token usage print(chat)  # Create session for different analysis type chat_gm <- chat_session("gm", "anthropic", "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001") } # }

Affects heatmap parallel plots. variable_order Character: "variance" (default) orders variance descending, "variance_reversed" variance ascending, "mean" orders mean value ascending, "mean_reversed" mean value descending, "original" preserves data order, "original_reversed" reverses data order, "alphabetical" sorts -Z, "alphabetical_reversed" sorts Z-. Cluster order always fixed input order. top_k Integer: maximum number variables display (default: Inf, shows variables). variables limit, top k variable features (variance) shown. Applies plot types. title Plot title

Otherwise, export cli version. title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: Unified interface interpreting psychometric analysis results LLMs. Supports fitted model objects, structured lists, persistent chat sessions efficient multi-analysis workflows.

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
code: interpret(   fit_results = NULL,   chat_session = NULL,   analysis_type = NULL,   llm_provider = NULL,   llm_model = NULL,   llm_args = NULL,   interpretation_args = NULL,   output_args = NULL,   ... )

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: fit_results One : Fitted model object: psych package: fa(), principal() lavaan package: cfa(), sem(), efa() mirt package: mirt() Structured list model components: FA: list(loadings = matrix, factor_cor_mat = matrix) list(loadings = matrix) (loadings factor_cor_mat can matrices data.frames) GM: list(means = matrix, covariances = array, proportions = numeric, z = matrix) IRT: yet implemented CDM: yet implemented chat_session Optional. chat_session object created chat_session token-efficient multi-analysis workflows (default = NULL). analysis_type Character. Type analysis ("fa", "gm", "irt", "cdm"). Required using structured list without chat_session. Automatically inferred chat_session provided (default = NULL). llm_provider Character. LLM provider (e.g., "openai", "anthropic", "ollama", "gemini"). Required chat_session NULL. Top-level convenience parameter (default = NULL). llm_model Character. Specific model use (e.g., "gpt-4o-mini", "claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022", "gemma2:9b"). NULL, uses provider default. Top-level convenience parameter (default = NULL). llm_args List llm_args object. LLM configuration settings. Can created llm_args passed plain list. Contains: system_prompt, params, word_limit, interpretation_guidelines, additional_info, echo. llm_provider/llm_model provided top-level, override values llm_args (default = NULL). interpretation_args List interpretation_args object. Model-specific interpretation configuration. Can created interpretation_args passed plain list. Contents vary model type. FA: cutoff, n_emergency, hide_low_loadings, sort_loadings (default = NULL). output_args List output_args object. Output configuration settings. Can created output_args passed plain list. Contains: format, heading_level, suppress_heading, max_line_length, silent (default = NULL). ... Additional arguments passed model-specific methods. Model-specific methods may require: variable_info: Data frame 'variable' 'description' columns (required FA)

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: Model-specific interpretation object: FA: fa_interpretation (see interpret) GM: gm_interpretation cluster profiles interpretations Future: irt_interpretation, cdm_interpretation

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: arguments named prevent positional confusion. function detects pattern using based arguments provided.

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: Pattern 1: Fitted Model Object Automatically extracts model components fitted objects. Pattern 2: Structured List custom data structures manual extraction. FA, provide loadings (required) optionally factor_cor_mat: Pattern 3: Chat Session (Token-Efficient) Reuse chat session across analyses save tokens. Pattern 4: Configuration Objects (Advanced) Use configuration objects reusable settings cleaner code.
code: interpret(   fit_results = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" ) interpret(   fit_results = list(     loadings = loadings_matrix,     factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat   ),   variable_info = var_info,   analysis_type = "fa" ) chat <- chat_session(analysis_type = "fa", llm_provider = "ollama", llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud") result1 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = model1, variable_info = var_info1) result2 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = model2, variable_info = var_info2) # Create configuration objects interp_config <- interpretation_args(analysis_type = "fa", cutoff = 0.4, n_emergency = 2) llm_config <- llm_args(word_limit = 100, additional_info = "Study context") output_config <- output_args(format = "markdown", silent = 1)  # Use in interpret() call interpret(   fit_results = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   interpretation_args = interp_config,   llm_args = llm_config,   output_args = output_config,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Or mix config objects with direct parameters (direct parameters override) interpret(   fit_results = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   interpretation_args = interp_config,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   word_limit = 150  # Overrides llm_config if it were provided )

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: see available parameters defaults, types, valid ranges, use show_interpret_args:
code: # Show common parameters (llm_args + output_args) show_interpret_args()  # Show all parameters for Factor Analysis show_interpret_args("fa")  # Show all parameters for Gaussian Mixture Models show_interpret_args("gm")

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: fa (Factor Analysis): psych::fa(), psych::principal(), lavaan::cfa/efa(), mirt::mirt() gm (Gaussian Mixture): mclust::Mclust() irt (Item Response Theory): yet implemented cdm (Cognitive Diagnosis Models): yet implemented

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: llm_provider llm_model exposed top-level parameters convenience, dual interface pattern allows argument passed either directly respective configuration object (llm_args, interpretation_args, output_args). keeps primary signature clean maintaining flexibility

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(psych) fa_model <- fa(mtcars[,1:4], nfactors = 2, rotate = "oblimin")  var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("mpg", "cyl", "disp", "hp"),   description = c("Miles per gallon", "Cylinders", "Displacement", "Horsepower") )  # Pattern 1: Fitted model result1 <- interpret(   fit_results = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Pattern 2: Structured list # Extract loadings from fitted model loadings <- as.data.frame(unclass(fa_model$loadings))  # Option A: Loadings only (orthogonal rotation) result2a <- interpret(   fit_results = list(loadings = loadings),   variable_info = var_info,   analysis_type = "fa",   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Option B: Loadings + factor correlations (oblique rotation) result2b <- interpret(   fit_results = list(     loadings = loadings,     factor_cor_mat = fa_model$Phi   ),   variable_info = var_info,   analysis_type = "fa",   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Pattern 3: Chat session (token-efficient for multiple analyses) chat <- chat_session(analysis_type = "fa", llm_provider = "ollama", llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud") result3a <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa_model, variable_info = var_info) result3b <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa_model2, variable_info = var_info2) print(chat)  # Check token usage } # }

title: Base Interpretation Class Structure — interpretation
text: Defines base interpretation class related S3 methods. Model-specific interpretation classes (fa_interpretation, gm_interpretation, etc.) inherit base class.

title: Base Interpretation Class Structure — interpretation
text: model-specific interpretation classes inherit base class. Common fields across interpretation types: analysis_type: Character. Type analysis ("fa", "gm", "irt", "cdm") component_summaries: List. Summaries factors/clusters/items/attributes suggested_names: List. LLM-generated names components interpretations: List. LLM-generated interpretations llm_info: List. Provider, model, token information chat: Chat session object fit_summary: List. Fit-specific summary information report: Character. Formatted text report elapsed_time: Numeric. Processing time seconds params: List. Analysis parameters

text: Creates configuration object interpretation settings. available parameters depend analysis_type.

title: Create Model-Specific Interpretation Configuration — interpretation_args
code: interpretation_args(analysis_type, ...)

title: Create Model-Specific Interpretation Configuration — interpretation_args
text: analysis_type Character. Type analysis: "fa" (factor analysis), "gm" (gaussian mixture), "irt" (item response theory), "cdm" (cognitive diagnosis model) ... Model-specific parameters. FA: cutoff, n_emergency, hide_low_loadings, sort_loadings. See Details.

title: Create Model-Specific Interpretation Configuration — interpretation_args
text: list class "interpretation_args" containing validated settings

title: Create Model-Specific Interpretation Configuration — interpretation_args
text: Factor Analysis (analysis_type = "fa"): cutoff: Numeric. Minimum loading value consider significant (default = 0.3) n_emergency: Integer. factor loadings cutoff, use top N highest loadings. 0, factors significant loadings labeled "undefined" (default = 2) hide_low_loadings: Logical. TRUE, variables loadings cutoff included LLM prompt (default = FALSE) sort_loadings: Logical. Sort variables loading strength within factors (default = TRUE) Note: Factor correlation matrices passed via fit_results parameter list structure: list(loadings = ..., factor_cor_mat = ...), via interpretation_args.

title: Create Model-Specific Interpretation Configuration — interpretation_args
code: # Factor analysis with default settings cfg <- interpretation_args(analysis_type = "fa")  # Factor analysis with custom settings cfg <- interpretation_args(   analysis_type = "fa",   cutoff = 0.4,   n_emergency = 3,   hide_low_loadings = TRUE )

Case transformation: "original", "lower", "upper", "title", "sentence", "snake", "camel", "constant" (default = "original") remove_articles Logical. Remove articles (, , ) labels (default = FALSE) remove_prepositions Logical. Remove prepositions (, , , etc.) (default = FALSE) max_chars Integer NULL. Maximum character length labels. dual purpose: label_type = "acronym", sets maximum acronym length (minimum fixed 3 chars); label types, applies post-processing truncation label exceeds length abbreviate Logical. Apply rule-based abbreviation long words (default = FALSE)

code: label_variables(   variable_info,   chat_session = NULL,   llm_provider = NULL,   llm_model = NULL,   label_type = "short",   max_words = NULL,   style_hint = NULL,   sep = " ",   case = "original",   remove_articles = FALSE,   remove_prepositions = FALSE,   max_chars = NULL,   abbreviate = FALSE,   label_args = NULL,   llm_args = NULL,   output_args = NULL,   echo = "none",   silent = 0 )

title: Generate Variable Labels Using LLM — label_variables
text: variable_info Data frame 'description' column (required) optional 'variable' column. 'variable' provided, names auto-generated V1, V2, V3, etc. chat_session Chat session object NULL. NULL, creates temporary session llm_provider Character. LLM provider (e.g., "anthropic", "openai", "ollama"). Required chat_session NULL llm_model Character NULL. Model name. NULL chat_session NULL, uses provider's default model label_type Character. Type labels: "short" (1-3 words), "phrase" (4-7 words), "acronym" (3-5 chars), "custom" (default = "short") max_words Integer NULL. Sets upper limit word count (overrides label_type presets EXCEPT "acronym"). Instructs LLM generate labels many words. Also applies post-processing truncation needed. effective using max_words reformat_labels(). Ignored label_type = "acronym". style_hint Character NULL. Style guidance LLM (e.g., "technical", "simple", "academic"). Influences LLM's choice terminology phrasing. sep Character. Separator words final output (default = " "). Post-processing - affect LLM generation. case Character. Case transformation: "original", "lower", "upper", "title", "sentence", "snake", "camel", "constant" (default = "original"). Post-processing - affect LLM generation. remove_articles Logical. Remove articles (, , ) labels (default = FALSE). Post-processing - affect LLM generation. remove_prepositions Logical. Remove prepositions (, , , etc.) (default = FALSE). Post-processing - affect LLM generation. max_chars Integer NULL. Sets upper limit character count. Instructs LLM generate labels within character limit. Works label types including "acronym" (controls acronym length). Also applies post-processing truncation needed. effective using max_chars reformat_labels(). abbreviate Logical. Apply rule-based abbreviation long words (default = FALSE). Post-processing - affect LLM generation. label_args List label_args object. Labeling-specific configuration. Created label_args. Direct parameters take precedence. llm_args List llm_args object. LLM configuration settings. Created llm_args. Direct parameters take precedence. output_args List output_args object. Output configuration settings. Created output_args. Direct parameters take precedence. echo Character. Echo level: "none", "output", "" (default = "none") silent Integer logical. Controls output verbosity (default = 0)

title: Generate Variable Labels Using LLM — label_variables
text: variable_labels object containing: labels_formatted Data frame formatted 'variable' 'label' columns labels_parsed Data frame unformatted LLM labels variable_info Data frame original variable information (variable, description) llm_response Raw LLM response text reformatting metadata List label_type, timestamp, token usage chat_session Chat session object reuse inspection

title: Generate Variable Labels Using LLM — label_variables
text: function works two phases: Semantic Generation: LLM generates natural language labels based descriptions Format Processing: Apply transformations (case, separators, abbreviation, etc.) Special case behaviors: case = "snake" automatically sets sep = "_" lowercase case = "camel" automatically sets sep = "" applies camelCase case = "constant" automatically sets sep = "_" uppercase

title: Generate Variable Labels Using LLM — label_variables
text: Parameters organized groups: Core: variable_info, chat_session, llm_provider, llm_model Semantic Generation (LLM-facing): label_type, max_words, max_chars, style_hint Format Processing (post-processing): case, sep, remove_articles, remove_prepositions, abbreviate Configuration Objects: labeling_args, llm_args, output_args Control: echo, silent

title: Generate Variable Labels Using LLM — label_variables
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Basic usage with explicit variable names labels <- label_variables(   variable_info = data.frame(     variable = c("q1", "q2", "q3"),     description = c(       "How satisfied are you with your job?",       "Rate your work-life balance",       "Years of experience"     )   ),   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Variable names are optional - will auto-generate V1, V2, V3, etc. labels <- label_variables(   variable_info = data.frame(     description = c(       "How satisfied are you with your job?",       "Rate your work-life balance",       "Years of experience"     )   ),   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Using configuration objects (dual-tier architecture) label_config <- label_args(   label_type = "short",   case = "snake",   remove_articles = TRUE )  llm_config <- llm_args(   word_limit = 50,   echo = "none" )  labels <- label_variables(   variable_info,   label_args = label_config,   llm_args = llm_config,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Direct parameters override config objects labels <- label_variables(   variable_info,   label_args = label_config,  # says case = "snake"   case = "camel",                 # This takes precedence!   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Reuse chat session for efficiency chat <- chat_session("label", "ollama", "gpt-oss:20b-cloud") labels1 <- label_variables(data1, chat_session = chat) labels2 <- label_variables(data2, chat_session = chat)  # Export results export_labels(labels, "variable_labels.csv") } # }

text: x object class "gm_interpretation" plot_type Character: "auto", "heatmap", "parallel", "radar", "" Character character vector: "means" (cluster means, default), "variances" (within-cluster SDs), "ratio" (/within variance ratio discrimination). vector provided (e.g., c("means", "variances")), faceted plot created panels data type, sharing variable axis labels easy comparison. cutoff Numeric threshold highlighting important values (default: 0.3) variables Character vector variables include (NULL ) orientation Character: "horizontal" (variables x-axis, default) "vertical" (clusters/values x-axis). Affects heatmap parallel plots. variable_order Character: "variance" (default) orders variance descending, "variance_reversed" variance ascending, "mean" orders mean value ascending, "mean_reversed" mean value descending, "original" preserves data order, "original_reversed" reverses data order, "alphabetical" sorts -Z, "alphabetical_reversed" sorts Z-. vector, variable ordering determined first value (e.g., c("means", "variances"), ordering based means). Cluster order always fixed original model order. top_k Integer: maximum number variables display (default: Inf, shows variables). variables limit, top k variable features (variance) shown. Applies plot types. centering Character: "none" (default, centering), "variable" (center variable mean across clusters), "global" (center values grand mean). applies ="means". Centering helps highlight cluster differences. layout Character: "auto" (default), "horizontal", "vertical". Controls facets arranged vector. "horizontal" places facets side--side (1 row, multiple columns), "vertical" stacks (1 column, multiple rows), "auto" uses horizontal layout (one row) facet counts. Ignored facet_nrow facet_ncol specified. facet_nrow Integer: Number rows facet layout (default: NULL). specified, overrides layout parameter. applies vector. facet_ncol Integer: Number columns facet layout (default: NULL). specified, overrides layout parameter. applies vector. ... Additional arguments passed specific plot functions

title: Plot GM Interpretation — plot.gm_interpretation
text: single value: ggplot2 object (heatmap/parallel) recordedplot object (radar). multiple values: faceted ggplot2 object panels data type. plot_type="": list containing three plot types.

title: Plot GM Interpretation — plot.gm_interpretation
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Basic plot (auto-selects best type, shows means) plot(gm_interpretation)  # Variance visualizations plot(gm_interpretation, what = "variances")  # Within-cluster standard deviations plot(gm_interpretation, what = "ratio")      # Discrimination ratios  # Specific plot type with variance plot(gm_interpretation, plot_type = "heatmap", what = "variances") plot(gm_interpretation, plot_type = "parallel", what = "ratio")  # Horizontal orientation (variables on x-axis, default) plot(gm_interpretation, plot_type = "heatmap", orientation = "horizontal") plot(gm_interpretation, plot_type = "parallel", orientation = "horizontal")  # Vertical orientation (clusters/values on x-axis) plot(gm_interpretation, plot_type = "heatmap", orientation = "vertical") plot(gm_interpretation, plot_type = "parallel", orientation = "vertical")  # Variable ordering in parallel plots (cluster order is always model order) plot(gm_interpretation, plot_type = "parallel", variable_order = "variance") plot(gm_interpretation, plot_type = "parallel", variable_order = "variance_reversed") plot(gm_interpretation, plot_type = "parallel", variable_order = "alphabetical")  # All plot types plots <- plot(gm_interpretation, plot_type = "all")  # Focus on specific variables plot(gm_interpretation, variables = c("var1", "var2", "var3"))  # Multiple what values with faceting (shares variable axis labels) plot(gm_interpretation, what = c("means", "variances"))  # Horizontal facets (side-by-side) plot(gm_interpretation, what = c("means", "variances", "ratio"), layout = "vertical")  # Custom facet layout with nrow/ncol plot(gm_interpretation, what = c("means", "variances", "ratio"), facet_nrow = 1)  # Force 1 row plot(gm_interpretation, what = c("means", "variances", "ratio"), facet_ncol = 1)  # Force 1 column plot(gm_interpretation, what = c("means", "variances", "ratio", "ratio"), facet_nrow = 2)  # Note: When what is a vector, variable ordering is based on the first type # For example, this orders by variance in the means: plot(gm_interpretation, what = c("means", "variances"), variable_order = "variance") # This orders by variance in the variances (swap order): plot(gm_interpretation, what = c("variances", "means"), variable_order = "variance") } # }

code: # Returns list with valid = TRUE validate_param("word_limit", 150, throw_error = FALSE) #> $valid #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $message #> NULL #>   # Returns list with valid = FALSE and error message validate_param("word_limit", 1000, throw_error = FALSE) #> $valid #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $message #> [1] "{.arg word_limit} must be between 20 and 500 (recommended range: 50-200 words)" #>   # Throws error if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ validate_param("word_limit", 1000, throw_error = TRUE) } # }

code: # Valid parameters params <- list(word_limit = 150, cutoff = 0.3, silent = 0) validate_params(params, throw_error = FALSE) #> $valid #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $results #> $results$word_limit #> $results$word_limit$valid #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $results$word_limit$message #> NULL #>  #>  #> $results$cutoff #> $results$cutoff$valid #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $results$cutoff$message #> NULL #>  #>  #> $results$silent #> $results$silent$valid #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $results$silent$message #> NULL #>  #> $results$silent$normalized #> [1] 0 #>  #>  #>  #> $invalid_params #> character(0) #>  #> $normalized #> $normalized$word_limit #> [1] 150 #>  #> $normalized$cutoff #> [1] 0.3 #>  #> $normalized$silent #> [1] 0 #>  #>   # Invalid parameters params <- list(word_limit = 1000, cutoff = 1.5) validate_params(params, throw_error = FALSE) #> $valid #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $results #> $results$word_limit #> $results$word_limit$valid #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $results$word_limit$message #> [1] "{.arg word_limit} must be between 20 and 500 (recommended range: 50-200 words)" #>  #>  #> $results$cutoff #> $results$cutoff$valid #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $results$cutoff$message #> [1] "{.arg cutoff} must be between 0 and 1 (got 1.5)" #>  #>  #>  #> $invalid_params #> [1] "word_limit" "cutoff"     #>  #> $normalized #> $normalized$word_limit #> [1] 1000 #>  #> $normalized$cutoff #> [1] 1.5 #>  #>
